webTitle: UK manufacturing expanding at fastest rate since 2011

fields.standfirst: 'Britain's factories are booming', analysts say, as manufacturing output rises over 4% on the year and 0.4% higher on the month
fields.body:
Hope that Britain's economic recovery is broadening beyond consumer spending have been boosted by news that manufacturers enjoyed their strongest annual growth for more than three years in April.

The Office for National Statistics said manufacturing output rose 0.4% on the month before, leaving it up 4.4% on the year, the fastest expansion since early 2011. That monthly growth was as forecast in a Reuters poll of economists.

That drove a pick-up for the wider industrial sector, which also includes utilities, mining and waste management. Industrial output was up 0.4% on the month and 3% on the year, again marking the strongest growth for more than three years.

Manufacturing slumped during the downturn and is still 7% below the economy's pre-crisis peak in early 2008. But the manufacturers' organisation EEF predicted this week that the sector will continue to rebound this year and with growth of 3.6% will outstrip the wider economy.

Analysts said the official numbers for April on manufacturing, which makes up a tenth of the UK economy, boded well for the government's push to rebalance away from reliance on domestic, consumer demand.

"Britain's factories are booming, enjoying their best spell of growth for four years," said Chris Williamson, chief economist at data specialists Markit, whose own survey on the sector showed solid growth continuing in May.

"The data not only indicate that the recovery has strong momentum, but also that the economy is rebalancing, though there is still a long way to go before manufacturing even regains its pre-recession size."

The ONS said the main boost to manufacturing in April on a year ago came from rubber, plastic and other non-metallic mineral products. There was also support from transport equipment and food and drinks.

David Tinsley, UK economist at BNP Paribas, said there were signs strong growth would continue.

"Overall this is a solid start to the second quarter – if manufacturing production went sideways in May and June it would still be up 1.1% over the quarter. And all survey evidence suggests a better performance than that is possible," he said.

webTitle: Imperial Tobacco shares light up after near £2bn logistics flotation

fields.standfirst: Leading shares pause for breath after recent rises but tobacco group outperforms
fields.body:
With the FTSE 100 taking a breather after two days of rises, Imperial Tobacco is bucking the trend after unveiling a near £2bn flotation of its logistics division.

The move will allow the company to concentrate on its core cigarette business, and involves selling a minority of its shares in Logista to institutional investors and floating the business on the Spanish stock market. Imperial had previously signalled the plan in February.

Imperial will retain a majority stake in Logista, which distributes cigarettes for Imperial and others in Spain, France, Italy and Portugal. Last year Logista had sales of £850m and earnings before interest and tax of £176m. Logista chief executive Luis Egido Galvez said:

We are well-positioned to benefit from economic recovery in our core markets.

Imperial put no valuation on Logista but analyst Martin Deboo of Jefferies said it could be worth £1.5bn to £1.7bn, and bring in some several hundred millions of cash for Imperial. He said:

We view this as a positive move for Imperial. It should realise a useful amount of cash and improve focus on the core tobacco business....which we think has many challenges, as well as opportunities.
Logista is partly conflicted under Imperial's ownership as it distributes on behalf of other tobacco manufacturers. We think a more arms length relationship might unlock some value otherwise inaccessible under full Imperial ownership. A useful cash inflow for Imperial, but keep it in proportion. With Imperial intending to float a minority of Logista, the implication is a cash inflow from float proceeds of some hundreds of £ millions. This can be used to reduce group net debt of around £9bn, with benefit to Imperial's cash returns model, which we are viewing increasingly as sustainable. However ultimately this is a £1bn [or so] semi-disposal by a £34bn behemoth, which has outperformed close peer British American Tobacco by around 20% since the inflection point last August. So while we see this as good business for Imperial, plenty of good news is in the price.

Damian McNeela at Panmure Gordon put a valuation on Logista of £1.1bn to £1.5bn:

Assuming Imperial retains a 51% share, this would indicate potential cash generation of £540m to £720m. Whilst we think the partial divestment of this non-core business is positive, we do not regard it as thesis changing. We maintain our hold recommendation.

Even so, Imperial is currently up 13p at £26.16, while the FTSE 100 has dipped 27.03 points to 6847.97. Mike McCudden at Interactive Investor said:

With the World Cup approaching investors look reluctant to tackle another move higher for equities in the short term. As global economic data continues to impress there is room for more upside but after what has been a historic run for equities many investors will be looking to lock in some profit. Indeed, with the VIX [volatility index] rising almost 4% yesterday it is clear that investors have seen enough and to chase markets higher from here is becoming a significantly riskier play.

Housebuilders continued to rise on hopes of new homes being built, with Barratt Developments up 1.9p to 377.8p.

Recent speculative takeover candidate Smith and Nephew is up 5p at £10.80.

But BT, boosted on Monday by a positive Nomura note, has fallen back 11.1p to 395p.

Continuing uncertainty over the platinum mining strikes in South African have sent Anglo American down 25p to 1446.5p and Lonmin 8.8p lower to 242p.

webTitle: Mike Ashley bonus plan faces shareholder vote again

fields.bodyText: Sports Direct yesterday unveiled a new plan to reward its billionaire executive deputy chairman, Mike Ashley – its third attempt to hand him a multimillion-pound incentive – but was immediately criticised by shareholders who bemoaned a lack of transparency and consultation. In April investors vetoed a £73m bonus for Ashley, the second time they had blocked an award for the tycoon, who is the company's founder and largest shareholder. In an attempt to get round investor resistance, the company returned with another proposal yesterday – this time enrolling Ashley in the company-wide staff bonus scheme. The plan hands members 25m free shares – worth just over £200m at the current share price – if the firm doubles earnings by 2019. But Sports Direct did not spell out how many executive directors or staff would be enrolled or how shares would be allocated. The vast majority of Sports Direct workers, mostly employed on zero-hours contracts, will get nothing. "It's extremely disappointing that they have proposed this scheme without any prior consultation," said one investor, who declined to be named. "There is also no detail as to any individual allocations, which is unhelpful." The failed bonus scheme in April was the second attempt by Sports Direct's board to reward its founder in recent years. A previous proposal was knocked back by shareholders because of concerns over the related performance targets. Shareholders have now been summoned to a general meeting on 2 July to vote on the revised plan. A company spokesman said no decision had been made on Ashley's share of the bonus. Ashley receives no salary, but owns 58% of the shares, after reducing his stake by 4% earlier in the year. Sports Direct, which has more than 600 shops in Europe, including 400 in the UK, is expected to announce £330m in earnings when it unveils its 2014 results in July.
